[21:59:45] ABSTRACT
[21:59:45] In  the  context  of  addressing  global  warming  issues  one  of  the
[21:59:45] possible  approaches  is  to  provide  individuals  with  tools  that
[21:59:45] support  behavior  change  toward  greener  practices,  as  for
[21:59:45] example  in  commuting.ACM Reference format:

[21:59:45] solutions, especially in the area of limiting the impact of human
[21:59:45] activities  on  the  environment  [2,  21,  22]  and  promoting  change
[21:59:45] of practices to become more sustainable [13].The  use  of  personal  informatics,  also  referred  as  quantified-
[21:59:45] self  or  self-tracking,  is  today  made  possible  by  the  variety  of
[21:59:45] tools and connected objects that are available to individuals and
[21:59:45] has  been  widely  analyzed in  the  HCI  research  community  [20].One recognized use of personal informatics is to support change
[21:59:45] management  [17].The  link  between  self-tracking  and  change
[21:59:45] management  is  in  the  reflexive  position  that  users  can  adopt
[21:59:45] regarding  their  behaviors  [19].Based  on  the  collected  data  and
[21:59:45] on  the  change  that  the  user  wants  to  achieve,  personal
[21:59:45] informatics  support  the  user  by  tracking  progress  toward  a
[21:59:45] desired direction.Many studies have focused on activity trackers that track the
[21:59:45] number  of  steps,  the  quality  of  sleep,  the  heart  pulsation  or
[21:59:45] burned calories.The majority of self-tracking practices target the
[21:59:45] domain  of  health  and  well-being  [11],  where  models  are  fairly
[21:59:45] simple: a step is a step, the number  of heart pulsations, and the
[21:59:45] number  of  calories  burned.Despite  the  required  low  level  of
[21:59:45] knowledge  and  relative  simplicity  of  the  underlying  models,
[21:59:45] some studies have already reported the difficulty that users may
[21:59:45] encounter when having to interpret the figures provided by the
[21:59:45] trackers [12, 15].When  considering  the  sustainable  mobility  domain,  we  can
[21:59:45] expect the difficulty of people in relating to the numbers to even
[21:59:45] increase,  since  the  phenomena  are  much  more  complex  and
[21:59:45] difficult  to  reduce.If  a  user  commutes  with  her  car  every  day,
[21:59:45] how  are  we going  to  compute  a  fixed  amount  of  money  that is
[21:59:45] spent  each  day  to  go  to  work  by  driving  a  car?Should  we
[21:59:45] include the initial cost of acquiring a car?The annual insurance
[21:59:45] fee? The  costs  of  maintenance?If  yes,  how  should  it  be
[21:59:45] integrated  in  the  daily  cost  of  driving  a  car  to  work?Then  we
[21:59:45] should  also  add  the  cost  associated  to  the  fuel  used  for  that
[21:59:45] specific trip.For the computation of CO2 emissions, in a similar
[21:59:45] way, many questions are open.How should we calculate the CO2
[21:59:45] emissions  of  someone  taking  the  bus?Should  we  take  into
[21:59:45] account  the  number  of  passengers  in  the  bus  on  that  specific
[21:59:45] day?Or  should  we  make  an  estimation  as  an  average?We
[21:59:45] targeted  specifically  financial  costs  and  CO2  emissions  due  to
[21:59:45] commuting  as  these  quantities  are  at  the  same  time  hard  to
[21:59:45] compute  accurately  for  people  and  can  have  a  relative  strong
[21:59:45] 144 ECCE 2019, September 10-13, 2019, BELFAST, <, United Kingdom
[21:59:45] impact  on  decision  making  for  taking  one  or  another  means  of
[21:59:45] transport.Current  online  tools  for  eco-feedback  on  mobility  are  based
[21:59:45] on  disaggregated  data  among  the  various  means  of  transport
[21:59:45] [10].This  means  that  for  any  mode  of  transport  and  a  given
[21:59:45] distance, there is a cost and an amount of CO2 emission that are
[21:59:45] associated  (for  instance  an  average  CO2  emission  per  distance
[21:59:45] and  per  passenger  for  public  transport).However,  as  the
[21:59:45] computation  is  complex  and  is  based  on  a  range  of  factors
[21:59:45] (owning  a  car,  having  a  public  transport  monthly  pass,  ride-
[21:59:45] sharing),  it  is  difficult  for  a  person  to  construct  an  accurate
[21:59:45] personal estimation of the impact of commuting practices  [3, 8,
[21:59:45] 23].There  are  studies  on  tools  supporting  greener  mobility
[21:59:45] practices [4, 5, 9, 14, 16], but to the best of our knowledge, none
[21:59:45] of  them  details  and  discusses  the  model  underlying  the
[21:59:45] computation.This  paper  aims  at  contributing  to  the  body  of
[21:59:45] knowledge about how people reason in practice about this type
[21:59:45] of data.2  Method and Settings
[21:59:45] In  order  to  study  how  people  understand  and  accept  figures  of
[21:59:45] CO2  emissions  and  costs  due  to  commuting,  a  diary  study  has
[21:59:45] been  conducted.We  have  chosen  this  methodology  as  it  is
[21:59:45] difficult  to  gather  information  on  commuting  practices  through
[21:59:45] observation over a long period of time.We involved a group of ten participants recruited through a
[21:59:45] snowball  sampling.The  ages  varied  from  27  to  56.Our
[21:59:45] participants  were  all  professionals,  qualified  as  engineers,
[21:59:45] computer  scientists,  doctors,  technicians,  school  teachers  and
[21:59:45] sales assistants.The  diary  study  was  divided  into  three  main  steps.The  first
[21:59:45] one  was  a  face-to-face  semi-directed
[21:59:45] interview  with  the
[21:59:45] participants  where  they  described  precisely  their  commuting
[21:59:45] practices: the means of transport used, the reasons for choosing
[21:59:45] a given means of transport on a given day, the preferences that
[21:59:45] they  may  have  for  one  or  another  means  of  transport  and  the
[21:59:45] constraints they may have in their professional or personal lives
[21:59:45] for commuting.In the second phase of the study, the participants filled a pen
[21:59:45] and paper diary during 20 working days.Each day, they had to
[21:59:45] indicate  the  date, the  means  of transport  used  that  day  and  the
[21:59:45] reason why they made that choice, if any.After the 20 days, the
[21:59:45] participants  returned  their  diaries  and  we  were  then  able  to
[21:59:45] compute all the figures regarding the cost and CO2 emissions of
[21:59:45] their commuting.The computation of the financial cost and CO2
[21:59:45] emission  figures  was  manually  performed  and  based  on  typical
[21:59:45] carbon footprint calculators publicly available at the time of the
[21:59:45] study  [10],  indicated  as  the  eco-calculator  in  the  rest  of  the
[21:59:45] paper.The third part of the study was a second interview with the
[21:59:45] participants, where we provided them with a compacted view of
[21:59:45] their commuting practices over the 20 days, where for each day,
[21:59:45] we  represent  for  the  user  the  means  of  transport  used  to go  to
[21:59:45] commute.We also shared with the participants a representation
[21:59:45] Cecile Boulard et al.of  the  financial  costs  and  CO2  emissions  for  each  day.All  the
[21:59:45] figures  produced  on  the  commuting  of  the  participants  were
[21:59:45] presented  to  them  during  interviews  with  all  the  required
[21:59:45] explanations in order to allow them to make sense of it.The goal
[21:59:45] of the second interview was to provide the participants with the
[21:59:45] compiled figures and then to discuss with them if and how those
[21:59:45] figures  made  them  think  about  their  commuting  practices  and
[21:59:45] choices.We  audio-recorded  all  interviews  and  collected  participants’
[21:59:45] diary  entries.All  the  interviews  were  entirely  transcribed  and
[21:59:45] analyzed together with the diaries.We identified themes using a
[21:59:45] thematic  analysis  [7].For  this  study,  we  inductively  identified
[21:59:45] themes  starting  from  the  data  trying  to  find  commonalities
[21:59:45] representation  of
[21:59:45] understanding.We describe our findings in next section.a  pre-existing
[21:59:45] than  having
[21:59:45] 3  Findings
[21:59:45] During  the  analysis,  the  emerging  central  theme  was  related to
[21:59:45] the  difficulties  that  participants  faced  during  the  interview  in
[21:59:45] understanding  and  accepting  the  figures  emerging  from  their
[21:59:45] commuting habits.The eco-calculator model takes a socially and
[21:59:45] politically rich concept like environmental impact and reduces it
[21:59:45] to measurable reference units like CO2 emissions and cost.Even
[21:59:45] within  a  sample  of  people  with  a  clear  disposition  towards
[21:59:45] questioning  their  own  environmental  impact  and  their  habits,
[21:59:45] there  was  a  tendency  to  perceive  the  figures  as  incomplete  and
[21:59:45] possibly unfair, as well as a difficulty in translating the data into
[21:59:45] actionable feedback, that is to say using it to make better choices
[21:59:45] specifically.transportation  options  available
[21:59:45] The findings that we report here come from the last phase of
[21:59:45] the study which is indeed the second interview when we gave to
[21:59:45] the participants’ feedback on their commuting practices.3.1 Understanding the data
[21:59:45] 3.1.1  Grasping abstract quantities.As  already  reported  in  [12],
[21:59:45] when  facing  data  without  having  access  to  information  on  the
[21:59:45] context  or  to  a  baseline,  users  may  struggle  to  make  sense  of
[21:59:45] them.A difficulty we observed was in positioning CO2 emission
[21:59:45] figures on some kind of directional scale – i.e.is it a little or a lot,
[21:59:45] good  or  bad,  and  in  relation  to  what?For  instance,  after  the
[21:59:45] researcher  told  P6  that  she  emitted  4000g  of  CO2  per  day,  she
[21:59:45] asked  and  commented:  “Is  it  quite  good?I  can’t  appreciate  it.”
[21:59:45] (P6).This  is  an  issue  as  it  does  not  support  users  in  taking
[21:59:45] actions  to  change  their  behaviors  toward  greener  practices.It
[21:59:45] demonstrates  that  there  is  a  need  to  build  a  baseline  of  CO2
[21:59:45] emissions  in  order  to  help  users  to  position  their  (commuting)
[21:59:45] practices also with respect to other people and for comparing the
[21:59:45] different options available in terms of means of transport.3.1.2  Understanding  the  model.Alongside  the  difficulty  in
[21:59:45] contextualizing  abstract  quantities  on  a  (potentially  normative)
[21:59:45] scale,  users  also  faced  a  challenge  in  understanding  what  the
[21:59:45] model actually took into account and what it left out.This can be
[21:59:45] an  issue  when  it  comes  to  the  perceived  (un)fairness  of  the
[21:59:45] model  (which  we  will  discuss  later),  but  also  when  weighting
[21:59:45] 145 “I Don’t Understand…” Issues in Self-Quantifying Commuting
[21:59:45] financial  costs  against  environmental  impact.P7  who  was
[21:59:45] mainly  riding  a  bike  or  using  the  tramway  to  go  to  work,  and
[21:59:45] only  occasionally  using  the  car,  identified  some  limits  of  the
[21:59:45] costs  representation,  presented  during  the  second  interview:  “I
[21:59:45] changed the tires on my bike during the course of the study.It was
[21:59:45] necessary, but you did not integrate this in the costs.” (P7)
[21:59:45] Because the cost of acquiring and maintaining of the owned
[21:59:45] means of transport were not included in the costs computed by
[21:59:45] the  eco-calculator  the  numbers  presented  to  P7  were  perceived
[21:59:45] as not complete.In a similar way, P3 who regularly took the public transport,
[21:59:45] questioned  the  cost  associated  to  the  monthly  pass.As  she
[21:59:45] explained:  “then  there  is  a  small  correction  factor  that  can  refine
[21:59:45] the  calculation  of  the  cost,  that  is  that  you  consider  only  the
[21:59:45] working days  whereas we can use the pass also in the week-end”.Here,  P3  meant  that  the  choice  of  dividing  the  price  of  the
[21:59:45] monthly pass only over 20 days, i.e.the working days, did not fit
[21:59:45] with  her  representation  of  cost of  the  monthly  pass.For  her,  it
[21:59:45] meant  that  she  could  get  in  a  bus  or  tram  anytime,  any  day  in
[21:59:45] the  month  and  so  the  cost  of  this  pass  should  have  been
[21:59:45] computed over the 30 days of the month.She explained that this
[21:59:45] would  have  seemed  fairer  to  the  representation  that  she  had  of
[21:59:45] the cost associated to the monthly pass.The  last  situation  we  highlight  in  this  section  refers  to  P10
[21:59:45] who  got  used  to  go  to  work  with  a  combination  of  means  of
[21:59:45] transport:  bus  and  kick  scooter.“So in the end the combination
[21:59:45] bus  +  kick  scooter  is  more  expensive  than  the  one  with  the  car?I
[21:59:45] don’t  understand.”  P10  expressed  the  incoherence  that  he
[21:59:45] perceived between the figures proposed by the diary and his own
[21:59:45] representation of costs.After this feedback, the researcher had to
[21:59:45] explain  and  detail  what  is  in  the  cost  associated  to  driving  (in
[21:59:45] this case only the fuel consumed for the trip) and the cost of the
[21:59:45] combination  bus  +  kick  scooter  (the  cost  of  one  bus  ticket).As
[21:59:45] the  distance  home-work  is  relatively  small  for  P10  (less  than
[21:59:45] 8km),  and  he  had  a  small  car  with  a  low  fuel  consumption,  the
[21:59:45] cost  of  the  fuel  for  8  km  was  less  than  a  ticket  in  the  bus.The
[21:59:45] limit of this computation of course is that it reduces the cost of
[21:59:45] the car to fuel consumption whereas the real cost of (owning and
[21:59:45] driving) a car is much higher than that.3.2 Accepting the data
[21:59:45] 3.2.1  When  the  model  fails  to  represent  specific  situations.The
[21:59:45] main objective of simulating a tool tracking commuting practices
[21:59:45] with  a  diary  was  to  get  a  first  evaluation  of  what  could  be  its
[21:59:45] role,  if  any,  in  incentivizing  users  to  adopt  greener  means  of
[21:59:45] transport.It  is  therefore  critical  that  the  data  is  not  only
[21:59:45] understandable,  as  discussed  in  the  previous  section,  but  also
[21:59:45] perceived  as  fair.Tracking  data  about  CO2  emissions  singles
[21:59:45] individuals  and  families  out  and  questions  their  habits  (and
[21:59:45] potentially their privileges) vis-à-vis a global problem.But to do
[21:59:45] so effectively the model has to be able to properly contextualize
[21:59:45] the  behavior  of  individuals  and  family  units  within  the  overall
[21:59:45] environmental impact of the collective (the city or metropolitan
[21:59:45] area, the country, etc.).Participant P9 lives more than 35 km away from work and is
[21:59:45] used  to  commute  either  with  car-sharing,  or  by  bus  or  by  car
[21:59:45] ECCE 2019, September 10-13, 2019, BELFAST, <, United Kingdom
[21:59:45] solo.According  to  the  eco-calculator  model  used  in  the  study,
[21:59:45] the greener option was car-sharing.The calculator was showing
[21:59:45] that  there  were  less  CO2  emissions  with  car-sharing  than  with
[21:59:45] the  bus.When  the  researcher  explained  that  to  P9,  he  was
[21:59:45] surprised  and  said:  “Ah… I emitted less CO2 in  car-sharing than in
[21:59:45] bus”.The  researcher explained  again  how  the  emissions  of  CO2
[21:59:45] for public transport are computed (each passenger on a bus emits
[21:59:45] 103,3  g  of  CO2  per  km).In  a  similar  situation,  P5  said  “which
[21:59:45] would  mean  that  car-sharing  would  produce  less  CO2  than  a  bus
[21:59:45] even when it is full?”.This result was really surprising for P5 and
[21:59:45] P9  because  it  did  not  comply  with  the  reality  of  facts  as  they
[21:59:45] perceived  them.When  P9  chose  to  go  by  bus,  his  car  was  not
[21:59:45] used  over  the  trip  whereas  when  he  chose  the  option  of  car-
[21:59:45] sharing,  the  bus  was  circulating  anyway.So,  from  his
[21:59:45] perspective,  the  travel  by  bus  cannot  correspond  to  a  higher
[21:59:45] emission of CO2 than the travel by car-sharing, because there is
[21:59:45] one less car on the road.To  go  further,  P10  added:  “yeah the thing about the bus is that
[21:59:45] you are not responsible for the itinerary, you use something that is
[21:59:45] there  regardless  and  you  do  not  directly  emit  anything.”  Which
[21:59:45] expressed  the  gap  between  a  global  representation  this
[21:59:45] participant had in opposition to a model that was providing daily
[21:59:45] feedback at an individual level.3.2.2  Challenging self-representations.The  previous  example
[21:59:45] shows  that  an  oversimplified  and  incomplete  model  can  create
[21:59:45] confusion  on  the relationship  between individual  and  collective
[21:59:45] means  of  transport  and  one’s  individual  impact  on  CO2
[21:59:45] is  particularly
[21:59:45] emissions  within
[21:59:45] problematic  given  that  one  of  the  explicit  goals  of  this  type  of
[21:59:45] tool  is  to  help  people  challenge  their  self-representation  and
[21:59:45] their habits.their  community. This
[21:59:45] The  potential  consequences  of  a  naïve  or  uninformed
[21:59:45] understanding of one’s own habits is illustrated by the reaction
[21:59:45] of  participant  P8,  working  at  almost  40  km  from  her  place  and
[21:59:45] highly  motivated  in  reducing  her  environmental  footprint.So,
[21:59:45] when  during  the  second  interview  the  researcher  explained  to
[21:59:45] the participant that she emitted 6200g of CO2 per day and that it
[21:59:45] was quite high compared to other participants, she  said: “I don’t
[21:59:45] understand,  I  only  take  the  train  and  ride  my  bike.”  In  her
[21:59:45] representation,  P8  only  considered  the  type  of  means  of
[21:59:45] transport  to  assess  if  it  produced  a  high  or  low  impact  on  the
[21:59:45] environment.She  had  put  aside  the  fact  that  when you live  far
[21:59:45] from  your  workplace,  the  CO2  emissions  due  to  transport  are
[21:59:45] necessarily  higher.The  data  allowed  the  participant  to  realize
[21:59:45] that  she  had  a  biased  understanding  of  the  environmental
[21:59:45] footprint.But while in this case the CO2 measurement provided
[21:59:45] by the model was helpful, it required an explanation on the part
[21:59:45] of  the  researcher  to  contextualize  the  data  to  this  person’s
[21:59:45] specific situation.4  Discussion and Conclusion
